moves.1. e4 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. Bg5 Be7: Here White seems to have an advantage in my opinion. Control of the centre is complete with the pawns on e4 and d4. White has two pieces developed to Blacks 1 and its white to move.
moves.7... Bxd4 8. Qd2 Qf6 9. f3 Bxc3:
Alternative is ...e5.

Black has his bishop in a fantastic position. Pushing the black pawn onto e5 solidifies makes blacks centre stronger aswell as allowing more space for the white squared bishop.
moves.10. Qxc3 Qxc3+ 11. bxc3: White now has doubled pawns to contend with. A future weakness for Black to target.
moves.11... Nd7 12. Ne2 Nb6 13. Bb3: Restricting the Black Knight and saving the Bishop.
moves.13... a5 14. a4 Bd7 15. O-O Rad8 16. Ng3: The Black knight cant come any further forward unless the pawn vacates e4.
moves.17. Rfe1 h5 18. Ne2 h4 19. h3 g5 20. Nd4: Black is playing a little risky pushing the pawns in front of his king.
moves.22. Ne2 d5 23. Nd4: White has moved the knight 4 times in his last six moves.
moves.23... c5 24. Nb5 Bxb5 25. axb5 c4: A brilliant Move. The Bishop is locked out of the game.
moves.26. Ba4 dxe4 27. Rxe4 e5 28. Ree1:
Black has a winning advantage. Black can never lose control of the d file as if a rook ever comes to d1 black captures it, after white recaptures black takes the bishop. There is then a serious threat of both of blacks rooks winding up on the second rank and attacking the King. 

A hard fought game between these two players. Good game.
